Planned changes to improve safety

Training events are conducted throughout the year at this facility to reinforce policies, procedures, and emergency response.  Risk management plans are reviewed annually to ensure current practices are appropriate.

General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

Due to the presence of EHS above threshold quantities, this facility is subject to:
•	OHSA PSM
•	EPA RMP
•	DHS CFATS

In addition, our facility complies with all other areas of regulation appropriate for a chemical distribution facility engaged in processes with hazardous materials, including, but not limited to:
•	CAA Section 112(r)(1) General Duty Clause
•	EPCRA sections 301, 303, 304, 311, 312, 313
•	RCRA
•	Spill prevention, control, and countermeasures rule
•	TSCA
•	FIFRA
•	OSHA 29 CFR 1910
•	US DOT 49 CFR

Risk management practices that drive our prevention program include:
•	Defined operational procedures
•	Hazard communication to employees
•	Employee training
•	Emergency planning and training
•	Security planning and training

Five-year accident history

We have had zero (0) accidental releases of regulated substances at this facility.  We have had zero (0) accidental releases of regulated substances at any previous facility.

Emergency response program

Our emergency response program covers typical emergency scenarios to a facility engaged in chemical distribution including:  fire, severe weather, and chemical release.  Our Emergency Response Plan details steps to be taken for reporting emergencies, evacuation, critical operations prior to evacuation, accounting for personnel, and training.  Employee training consists of presentations, tabletop exercises, and drills.  Chemical release emergencies are of particular concern, therefore procedures and training - intended to protect workers and the community – have been developed to respond appropriately.  Briefly, workers are trained to identify the severity of an accidental release.  Events that pose an immediate danger to life and health are cause for evacuation and reporting to local emergency responders.  Non-life threatening (incidental) release events will prompt spill countermeasure activities by trained c

Water Solutions Unlimited, Inc. – East Peoria, IL
RMP – Executive Summary

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies

Water Solutions Unlimited Inc. (WSU) has highly hazardous chemicals on-site that require the protection of our employees and environment.  The major objective of our Risk Management Program is to prevent unwanted releases of hazardous chemicals especially into locations that could expose employees and others to serious hazards.  By targeting highly hazardous chemicals, applicable standards can aid management in their efforts to prevent or mitigate episodic chemical releases that could lead to a catastrophe in the workplace and possibly in the surrounding community.

Safe work practices and procedures, along with safety rules, have been established in order to create the safest workplace possible.  The practices, procedures, and rules are reviewed on an annual and as needed basis and improved as necessary.  The practices, procedures, and rules are also communicated to workers and expected to be followed at all times.

Senior management demonstrates their commitment to continuous improvement in environmental, health, safety & security through annual review of policies, procedures, communication, and resources.

Facility and regulated substances handled

Our facility is approximately 7000 sq. ft. warehouse space.  The warehouse is engaged in chemical distribution activities including:  storage, handling, packaging, mixing/blending, shipping, and receiving.  These activities include several hazardous chemicals (sodium hypochlorite, hydrochloric acid), non-hazardous materials (phosphate salts, ammonium sulfate), and some EHS (chlorine).  While most chemical products do involve mixing and/or repackaging, no EHS are ever mixed or repackaged at our facility.
